title: 110_s1569
content: The "Veterans Advocacy Act of 2007" may provide legal assistance to veterans and members of the armed forces to receive health care, benefits, and services. The "Veterans Advocacy Act of 2007" mandates a pilot program to assess using eligible entities to provide legal services for veterans and members of the Armed Forces in accessing healthcare, benefits, and services. The program will be carried out through grants awarded to selected entities for providing legal services at no cost to veterans and service members. The pilot program under the "Veterans Advocacy Act of 2007" includes awarding grants to eligible entities for legal training on health and benefits programs of the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary will award 10 grants, with at least five going to State-designated protection and advocacy systems. Grants must be awarded within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The pilot program under the "Veterans Advocacy Act of 2007" awards grants to eligible entities, with grant amounts ranging from $25,000 to $100,000. Grants cannot exceed one year in duration, and recipients must avoid representing veterans and Armed Forces members in frivolous benefit claims. Eligible entities include State-designated protection and advocacy systems. Eligible entities for the pilot program must not be part of the Department of Veterans Affairs or the Department of Defense. They must provide legal services by licensed attorneys with experience in assisting veterans, Armed Forces members, or persons with disabilities. A panel appointed by the Secretary evaluates applications and selects grant recipients from among eligible entities. Members of the panel evaluating applications for the pilot program shall be appointed in equal numbers from various groups including officers and employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs, Department of Defense, veterans service organizations, organizations serving Armed Forces members, attorneys representing veterans, and attorneys from State-designated protection and advocacy systems. The pilot program requires eligible entities to submit an application to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, including details on the population to be assisted and outreach efforts to notify members of the Armed Forces and veterans. The pilot program requires eligible entities to submit an application to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, including details on the population of attorneys to be trained and outreach efforts to notify attorneys of the training availability. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs regarding the pilot program, detailing the number of veterans and Armed Forces members assisted, along with the services provided. The term "State-designated protection and advocacy system" refers to a system in a State that protects the rights of individuals with developmental disabilities. In accordance with the Developmental Disabilities Assistance and Bill of Rights Act of 2000, funding of $1,000,000 from the Defense Health Program in the U.S. Troop Readiness, Veterans' Care, Katrina Recovery, and Iraq Accountability Appropriations Act, 2007 is allocated for the veterans service organization. This funding is available for fiscal year 2008 and can be used for the specified purposes without a time limit.
